Award.AwardTitle: Peers Organized by Discipline for Success

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Pell Institute data indicates that financially needy students persist and graduate at a lower rate than college peers. The Florida Department of Education data shows that over half of the Duval County School District's 125,022 students are on the free and reduced school lunch program, and U.S. Census statistics reveal that less than 25% of Jacksonville's age 25 and over population has earned a baccalaureate degree. This project at Florida State College at Jacksonville (FSCJ) will address these needs through scholarships for financially needy science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) students with additional student support for academic, transfer and career success. The project will include intensive mentoring for at least 56 academically talented, financially needy students in the sciences, mathematics, and aerospace engineering technology programs at the college. The college will collaborate with multiple STEM industry partners that will provide hands on work experiences for students, networking opportunities with STEM professionals, and job placement assistance. Since 45 percent of all undergraduates nationwide attend community college, information gained through this project will help improve academic success and graduation and job placement for students beginning higher education at community colleges, institutions rapidly becoming one of the pipelines for STEM majors.

The project will strengthen: 1) outreach to students in information technology and engineering technology; 2) recruitment of first year students; and 3) awareness of the STEM-related baccalaureate degrees offered by the college. Participants will be expected to significantly outpace peers with regards to retention, completion, academic success, and progression to STEM baccalaureate degrees and occupations. Supporting this dynamic effort will be several key organizations including CareerSource (the Regional Workforce Board) and Duval County Public Schools. This project will have internal support from the Office of Student Success, the Pre-College Outreach Department, Career Development Center, Office of Services for Students with Disabilities, Library and Learning Commons, and the Scholarship Office. This program will promote academic success, retention and completion through an enhanced academic support and peer-mentoring system called PODS (Peers Organized by Discipline for Success); small groups of 3-5 students supported by a faculty mentor and peer tutors to form a triangle for success. Recipients will participate in "Ready, Set, STEM!" two day orientations, the College's STEM Club, how to study science seminars, and will receive assistance from science and mathematics tutors. Activities will include field experiences, site visits to STEM-related businesses and institutions, transfer workshops, "Speaking of STEM" lectures, development of career education plans with each student, and scientific internships and symposia. Extensive evaluation and broad dissemination of the PODS model and Orientation Tool Kit will support implementation of successful project elements in other settings and within other disciplines. Open access to raw project data (guarded for student confidentiality) will support further research into processes, populations, and generalizable settings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Peers Organized by Discipline for Success2 (PODS2) expanded on the efforts of our 2010 -2015 S-STEM PODS model and extended it college wide to include: new STEM disciplines; additional faculty members and peer tutors; early, first year recruitment; an intensive project orientation; and enhanced transfer opportunities into onsite STEM baccalaureate degree programs. Through the PODS2 project, we increased the number of academically talented but financially needy students in science disciplines, mathematics, aerospace engineering technology, information technology and engineering technology (advanced manufacturing) as we prepared them to transfer successfully into a baccalaureate degree program or enter the workforce with a technological certificate or associate degree. We accomplished this through the following activities:

1.  We provided scholarships to 129 financially needy, academically talented and engaged STEM students, including those from underrepresented groups. This number exceeded our original target of 56 students by an additional 73 students.

Although students in the Associate of Arts degree program are not required to declare a major, we chose students who had an intended STEM major and were intending to pursue a STEM major upon transferring to a four-year program at a college or university. We increased efforts to recruit first year college students by utilizing FSCJ’s existing outreach initiatives in the high schools (such as the College Reach Out Program) and by utilizing second year PODS students in addition to faculty STEM mentors to help recruit students.

2. We promoted academic success, retention and completion through an enhanced academic support and peer-mentoring system coupled with opportunities for research, applied and internship experiences.

PODS2 utilized techniques, such as virtual support and web-based resources, and offered the following student services: PODS2 utilized unique features that have been shown to enhance student success, including  creating small, mentored cohorts of 3-5 students each, actively engaging PODS2 students to recruit additional students, and developing a voluntary student orientation. This orientation explained the PODS2 program requirements to students, helped students register for classes, and offered an interactive workshop on “How to Study Science” to PODS2 Scholars. Each student worked with a faculty mentor to develop an individual career education plan as a “roadmap” to success. Additional activities included involvement in the College’s STEM Club and personalized tutoring from natural sciences, mathematics and computer technology tutors. We also offered an opportunity for field experiences, site visits to STEM-related businesses and institutions, coordinated opportunities to engage in research and work internships, and participation in research symposia, expositions and fairs.

PODS2 also benefited from “lessons learned” in the previous S-STEM Scholars program that helped in identifying qualified applicants by 1)  having an open deadline for scholarship applications to accelerate the number of applications received, 2) having faculty help recruit scholarship applicants, and 3) preparing counselors with accurate scholarship requirement information.

3. We prepared participants to successfully transfer to baccalaureate degree programs in a STEM fields through the following activities:

We advised students on the appropriate course prerequisites required for entrance into their specific STEM majors.  Beginning in 2009, FSCJ began offering baccalaureate degrees but many students were unaware of these offerings. Part of the PODS2 activities was making our students more aware of the STEM–related bachelor degrees offered at the College, which include:

Biomedical Sciences (B.S.): this program consists of a rigorous, hands-on laboratory-based curriculum that emphasizes concentrations in biological sciences and biochemistry to prepare students for direct entry into analytical/research laboratories.  

Computer Systems Networking and Telecommunications (B.A.S.): this program equips students with technical and management skills required to become network professionals in system design and analysis; network management and control; network flow optimization; network configuring and troubleshooting; and information security.

Digital Media (B.A.S.): this curriculum encompasses hands-on instruction in state-of-the-art computer labs working on individual and team-based critical path projects.

Information Technology Management (B.A.S.): this program educates, mentors, trains, and develops students that can manage and supervise IT personnel and projects using effective communication skills and knowledge of evolving technologies.

4. We provided participants with resources for gaining STEM-related employment including resume writing advice, interviewing skills, and job search strategies.

With the PODS program expansion, the College was able to award scholarships in technical areas of local need in Northeast Florida, particularly information technology and engineering technology. We provided scholarships to 129 academically talented, financially needy students in the sciences, mathematics and computer technology fields. The demographic breakdown included 66 females and 63 males,  32 African Americans, seven Asians, 52 Caucasians, six Hispanics, six Middle Eastern students, and 26 students who did provide information regarding race/ethnicity. The mean age for recipients was 30.4 years of age (20 – 55). The target GPA for the students was 2.75.  The students in the program maintained a mean GPA of 3.36. The target goal for graduation was 80% and so far, 83 of the 129 students have graduated (64%). Twenty students are still completing their degrees.
